page.title: 13Transport in Pontycymer
page.content: Before industry came to Ponytcymer the chief means of travel was by horse and cart. Communications and industry developed together. First came the tramlines, and then in 1872, the Ogmore Railway was extended into the Garw valley and in 1886 a railway was built from Brynmenyn to the valley. The railways were originally built for both coal and passenger transport, but the latter ceased in 1953. The railway lines run in parallel to the Garw River, as do the two main roads, Bridgend Road and the A4064 which provides a link with the M4. The only public service in Pontycymer and the valley today is the national Welsh Bus service, but this has also deteriorated in recent years.
